The bliss refuses to look away from spiritual movements of life, whether positive or negative. As Ra says, 'the crown is already upon the head.'
symbols: Kneeling woman in white playing three-stringed harp - feminine side playing masculine as musical instrument; mind, body, spirit turned over to governing power of feminine spirit
Male head on harp - masculine spiritual self offering itself to be played by the hidden feminine
Winged lingam-yoni above - successful completion of Great Work; intimate union between transparent and hidden selves; ability to fly to the Sun itself
Circle of flowers in sky around lingam-yoni - sacred circle now mobile; every part of Creation revealed as holy ground; daily activity becomes sacramental
Four creatures of sphinx - human, lion, bull, eagle; four elements; four phases of human activity; full integration

levels.personal: Stepping closer to ideal by trusting it is already realized within us. Living within constant flow of spiritual energy from Creator into manifestation. Not looking away from spiritual movements of life, whether positive or negative.
levels.interpersonal: One person gives themselves over, body and soul, to the other. He trusts she knows best way to use his abilities; she depends on him to link her to manifest world. Roughly characteristic of guru-chela relationship; most easily experienced in sexual intercourse.
levels.social: Constructive anarchist social organization—the group itself knows best what is best for it. Individuals trust that only through expression of desires of the group will highest realization come about. Faithful servants and instruments of higher intentions of group.

polarizedExpressions.rightHandPath: Masculine submits to higher will embodied by feminine. Offers himself fully as servant, confident a more harmonious world will result. She is embodiment of infinite love and tenderness—works to realize his deepest desires in ways better than he imagined.
polarizedExpressions.leftHandPath: Taming and training the Shadow (feminine side). Using Lesser Cycle to empty out Shadow and reorient toward conscious self's intention. The dragon is mounted—she is far more powerful but his control is so thorough she acts out his wishes. The jealous gods of religious myths.

distortions: Partial surrender - Attempting to hold back part of self from the process
Premature Avatar - Claiming union not yet achieved
Cultism - Perverting the group trust into servitude

raQuotes.text: Thus the daily activity becomes sacramental in nature.
The crown is already upon the head.

21.jungian: The World represents the archetype of wholeness—the mandala that contains all opposites in dynamic balance. The Avatar lives as expression of the Self: ego transparent to transpersonal purpose, individual will aligned with cosmic pattern. The feminine playing the masculine as instrument reverses ordinary ego-dominance: consciousness serves the unconscious rather than attempting to control it. The four creatures mark completion: all functions integrated, all directions honored. The flower circle in the sky indicates that sacred space is now portable—the individuated person carries their center wherever they go. This is the goal imagined: wholeness as process, not achievement.
21.lacanian: The World figures the 'pass' (la passe)—the completion of analysis where the subject assumes their sinthome and takes responsibility for their mode of jouissance. The Avatar has traversed the fantasy and emerged on the other side, no longer mystified by their own desire. The feminine playing the masculine marks the shift from ego-mastery to authorized surrender: the subject allows themselves to be 'played' by the unconscious they have come to trust. The lingam-yoni's flight represents desire no longer anchored in specific objects but mobile, capable of investing anywhere. The left-hand path version (dragon-riding) shows the same structure serving opposite ends: power for self versus power for other.

22.name: The Fool
22.framework: The Choice is the unifying archetype expressing the holistic nature of the entire third density experience. It is both beginning and end—the spiritual neophyte stepping into mystery and the one exiting third density firmly committed to their path. Ra calls it 'relatively fixed and single' compared to other archetypes. The Choice represents the locus of 'free will, in the full sense'—the self that chooses between the two moral paths.
22.character: The Traveler is neither masculine nor feminine—pre-gender. Closely related to Campbell's Hero but the Traveler is the audience experiencing life through the protagonist's eyes, existing beyond the story's confines. Wants to know what the mysterious world is like. Driven by curiosity, faith that it will work out, and lack of awareness of danger. The Traveler is motivated by curiosity and spiritual longing. Empowering capacities are faith and naivety. Virtue is humility. Home is everywhere and nowhere.
symbols: Blindfolded human figure walking toward ocean - inability to see through illusion to reality; stepping forward into mystery
Crocodile with mouth open - dangers lurking on the path; possibility of mental or spiritual disfigurement, not just physical
Fallen column with writing - mainstream social structures; the popular conception of good life that has failed to satisfy spirit's yearning
Solar eclipse - the darkness of not knowing; also the choice between two moral paths (light and dark)
Two bags on left shoulder (front and back) - meager possessions for journey; some known, some hidden; contracts and core values
Black walking stick in right hand - ability to stay upright on the road; somewhat inhibited since behind the figure
Half-nakedness - vulnerability to dangers of the path

levels.personal: The subjective witness present to each moment. The eye that does not see itself. Usually identifies with various active elements of psyche, but occasionally steps back to observe and render judgment about whether to keep going as usual.
levels.interpersonal: The Traveler who joins others in their home (mental, physical, spiritual). Welcome company because adaptable; jack of all trades; chameleon striking others as both familiar and mysterious. Listens more than speaks. The persona of personality itself—can take on any other persona.
levels.social: The immigrant, the well-traveled newcomer. Experience more varied than those of culture entered. Easy to understand new environment (some things remain same everywhere) but hard to lay down roots—always feeling like outsider.

polarizedExpressions.note: The Choice is 'relatively fixed and single.' It represents the chooser, not the choice made. The experience of being witness to objective world is more or less consistent across all human beings. The responsibility for making a choice does not require dual polarized expressions of the chooser herself.

distortions: Arrogance (spiritual cynicism) - Rejecting the mysterious; refusing the journey because certainty is demanded before stepping forward
Foolhardiness - Confusing faith with recklessness; stepping forward without any preparation
Refusing to choose - Remaining in perpetual indecision; the journey never begins
Loss of witness perspective - Becoming so identified with a persona that the Traveler forgets she can move on

raQuotes.text: A proper understanding of Archetype Twenty-Two is greatly helpful in sharpening the basic view of the Significator of Mind, Body, and Spirit and, further, throws into starker relief the Transformation and Great Way.
We are all Bozos on this bus.

22.jungian: The Fool represents the archetype of the Eternal Youth (puer aeternus) and the Wise Old Man simultaneously—beginner's mind that is also complete wisdom. The Traveler is the Self before and after differentiation: the same consciousness that enters incarnation and exits it, unchanged by the journey yet enriched by experience. The blindfold marks the necessary not-knowing that protects free will: if we saw clearly, we could not choose authentically. The crocodile (shadow danger) and fallen column (collective failure) frame the individual's passage. The Fool is who we are beneath all roles: witness to our own drama, capable of departing any scene when it no longer serves.
22.lacanian: The Fool figures the subject of the unconscious—the dimension of subjectivity that is not the ego, not the self-image, but the gap or discontinuity that makes self-consciousness possible. The Traveler is the barred subject ($): divided, lacking, yet capable of desire precisely because of this division. The blindfold represents structural not-knowing: the subject cannot see themselves seeing, cannot know the desire that motivates their knowing. The two bags are the objet a (behind, unknown) and the ego-ideal (in front, known): what actually causes desire versus what we believe causes it. The Fool's 'relatively fixed' nature reveals the subject as purely formal: not a substance but a position, the same empty place through which all content passes.
